descriptionSet.description: A print of the third incarnation of Vishnu, known as Varaha rescuing the earth which was seized by the demon, Hiranyaksha. Here the earth is depicted in the form of a globe. Varaha as seen in the print has the head of a boar and the body of a man, eight hands and holds various weapons and religious and symbolic articles.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

hra:item.hra:value: description-en: A print of the third incarnation of Vishnu, known as Varaha rescuing the earth which was seized by the demon, Hiranyaksha. Here the earth is depicted in the form of a globe. Varaha as seen in the print has the head of a boar and the body of a man, eight hands and holds various weapons and religious and symbolic articles. (gs/sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Vishnu in his third incarnation as the boar (Varaha) lifts up earth using his horns. The earth is shown here as a gridded terrestrial globe instead of the customary goddess Prithvi. (Sumathi Ramaswamy)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: In monumental art, votive images, and illuminated manuscripts from the middle centuries of the first millennium C. E., Earth (Prithvi, Bhu Devi) was conventionally depicted as a demure young woman who clings to the large virile boar as he rescues her from the clutches of evil. Note that in this print—as indeed in many other such visualizations of this primeval event over the course of the 20th century—the anthropomorphic female divinity gives way to the impersonal spherical globe with grids and territories marked on its surface. Rather than “science” triumphing over “religion,” there is an easy co-existence as divine body and geo-body rest side by side. (Sumathi Ramaswamy)(gs)
